description: From Middle English wald, wold, from Old English wald, weald (“highland covered with trees, wood, forest”), from Proto-West Germanic *walþu, from Proto-Germanic *walþuz, from Proto-Indo-European *wel(ə)-t-. Doublet of weald.

entries.meaning: (archaic, regional) An unforested or deforested plain, a grassland, a moor.
examples: Take counsel, sever from my lot your lot,
Dwell in your pleasant places, hoard your gold;
Lest you with me should shiver on the wold,
Athirst and hungering on a barren spot.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A wood or forest, especially a wooded upland.
(archaic, dialect, West Country, Dorset, Devon) Old.
